name: Winona Friesz
history:
Winona "Smokey" Friesz – Callsign: Smokey

Age: Mid-50s
Affiliation: Union, Lancer Pilot (Harrison Armory Cybernetics)
Family: Dr. Helena Orlan-Friesz (wife), Elias "Eli" Friesz (son)

Born in Fire

Winona Friesz was born on Varkana, a world that had survived without Union for generations. Nestled in the Outer Systems, it was self-sufficient, fiercely independent, and deeply suspicious of outside governance. The government fostered a strong sense of nationalism, resilience, and self-reliance, teaching its people that Union’s promises of progress were just a mask for control.

For centuries, Varkana had stood alone. And its people were proud of that.

When Union finally made contact, there was no war. No orbital bombardment. No occupation. Varkana’s leadership—after decades of maintaining sovereignty—chose to join peacefully. They cited long-term sustainability, technological advancements, and interstellar trade. To many, it was a new beginning.

To others, it was a betrayal.

Winona was among those who refused to accept that their leaders had simply “changed their minds.” To him, to his community, something didn’t add up. Had Union bribed them? Threatened them? Replaced them? No true Varkanan would surrender like this.

These fears drove him into the arms of the Free Varkana Movement, a militant faction that saw itself as a last line of defense against Union’s influence. They believed that if they struck hard enough—if they made the cost of occupation too high—they could force their world to reclaim its independence.

And so, Winona became a fighter.

He believed in the cause. Believed in the men and women fighting alongside him. They weren’t terrorists—they were patriots.

Until the day he proved himself wrong.

The Bombing

The plan was simple: detonate an explosive at a government complex suspected of coordinating with Union officials. It was meant to send a message. It was meant to shake Varkana’s leadership, to show them that the people had not surrendered.

It was never supposed to kill civilians.

Winona had convinced himself of that—right up until the moment he pressed the detonator.

The explosion tore through the building, collapsing walls and igniting the sky with fire and debris. At first, he felt nothing but cold satisfaction. But then came the screams. The smoke cleared just enough for him to see the bodies—government workers, Union diplomats, civilians who had no part in this war.

And children.

He had told himself there would be no innocents in that building. That it was a military target. But the truth had never mattered. He had never checked. He had let his hatred, his certainty, blind him.

Then, the second explosion hit—his own charge, detonating too soon.

He was caught in the blast.

Shrapnel tore through his flesh, ripping away his jaw, his nose, his limbs. The heat burned deep into his muscles, searing through nerves, reducing him to a broken, ruined husk. He collapsed onto the scorched earth, choking on blood and ash, drowning in the sounds of dying men and women.

And as he lay there, gasping for breath, dying among the very people he had killed—he realized the truth.

Varkana’s leaders had never been coerced.

They had chosen peace.

And he had just murdered his own people for nothing.

The pain was unbearable. The horror of what he had done was worse.

He welcomed death. He wanted it.

But it never came.

Rebuilt by the Enemy

Winona woke up in a Union hospital.

He shouldn’t have survived. Most of his body was gone, his flesh charred beyond repair, his limbs reduced to ragged, bloodied stumps. And yet—Union had saved him.

Even knowing who he was.

Even knowing what he had done.

They could have left him there. Let him rot. Let him become a cautionary tale. But instead, they chose mercy.

And that? That broke him more than any explosion ever could.

Everything he had believed—the lies, the fear, the hatred—crumbled beneath the weight of his own actions. He had been the villain.

And Union? The so-called enemy?

They had been the ones to save him.

Atonement

Rebuilding him wasn’t easy. His body was shattered beyond natural repair. To restore him, Union partnered with Harrison Armory, providing him with state-of-the-art cybernetic enhancements.

The transition was… unsettling. His new body was stronger, faster, more durable than before—but it wasn’t his. His reflection was unrecognizable. His cybernetics were so advanced, so integrated, that even he struggled to tell where the machine ended and the man began.

But that didn’t matter. Because he had made a choice.

Winona renounced the Free Varkana Movement. He dedicated himself fully to Union, not out of obligation, but out of a desperate need to atone.

For the past thirty years, he has served as a Lancer, fighting for Union with a grin on his face and a weight in his soul.

To those who meet him, Winona is chipper, upbeat, always quick with a joke. He carries himself with an easy charm, an almost unsettling lightness, even in the face of war.

But it’s not because he doesn’t care.

It’s because he has to.

Because if he ever stops smiling, if he ever lets himself dwell on the past—on the people he killed, on the screams he left behind—he might never crawl out of that darkness again.

The Family He Doesn’t Deserve

At some point, against all odds, Winona found love.

Dr. Helena Orlan-Friesz, the Union field surgeon who had helped save him, saw something in him—something worth saving. She was sharp, pragmatic, and had no patience for his nonsense, which made her the perfect counterbalance to his chipper, self-deprecating attitude.

Over time, what began as mutual understanding turned into something deeper.

Together, they built a life.

They had a son, Elias "Eli" Friesz, now sixteen. Eli is smart, quick-witted, and too perceptive for his own good. He sees the cracks in his father’s armor, the pain Winona refuses to talk about. And unlike his father, Eli isn’t convinced that Union is perfect.

He asks hard questions, the kind that make Winona’s cybernetic fingers twitch.

"Dad, do you ever wonder if you’re just following orders again?"

Winona doesn’t have an answer for that.

Because if he lets himself question Union, if he allows even the slightest doubt to creep in—then he has to ask himself if he was wrong again.

And that? That terrifies him.

So he keeps moving forward. Keeps fighting, smiling, following orders.

Because that’s what he owes the dead.

And if Union needs him to do something grim, something awful, something others won’t?

He’ll do it.

Because Union saved him.

Because he will never let himself be that man again.

systems.flavorDescription: With the right tweaks, it becomes possible to dump excess heat into the area directly surrounding a chassis. Explosive venting is an unsanctioned, unsafe method of sudden cooling that has nevertheless been adopted by many pilots.

weapon.flavorDescription:
Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-I (T-1) line is defined by powerful, reliable, and conventional-kinetic ranged and melee weapons, including the GMS assault rifle, heavy machine gun, shotgun, pistol, and various light and heavy blades. Reliable galactic standards, the GMS T-1 line is the most widely used mech-scale line of weaponry across the galaxy. Echoing the Everest’s design notes, T-1 weapons are simply designed, with few (if any) moving parts, intended to be used in or adaptable to any environment.

Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-I (T-1) line is defined by powerful, reliable, and conventional-kinetic ranged and melee weapons, including the GMS assault rifle, heavy machine gun, shotgun, pistol, and various light and heavy blades. Reliable galactic standards, the GMS T-1 line is the most widely used mech-scale line of weaponry across the galaxy. Echoing the Everest’s design notes, T-1 weapons are simply designed, with few (if any) moving parts, intended to be used in or adaptable to any environment.

Between the thick arboreal environment of Hercynia, the swarm tactics of the Egregorians, and the ineffectual performance of slug ammunition, the need for wide-effect weapons was apparent. GMS quick developed the Krakatoa – a thermobaric flamethrower – and disseminated it to affiliates. The Krakatoa was quickly adopted by Union’s Marine Expeditionary Forces, seeing heavy use in the depths of the Hercynian continental jungles thanks to its stability, reliability, and stopping power.
Later reworked and adopted by the Armory following the resolution of the Hercynian Crisis, the Krakatoa has become a popular tool for the creation of area-of-denial firebreaks.

systems.flavorDescription:
The Armory-designed auto-cooler is a simple, persistent system that actively mitigates heat generation.
Thermal dump thresholds are determined by fleet engineers, though pilots can adjust levels on the fly – this automatic management frees the pilot up to focus on other, more pressing tactical concerns.

With the right tweaks, it becomes possible to dump excess heat into the area directly surrounding a chassis. Explosive venting is an unsanctioned, unsafe method of sudden cooling that has nevertheless been adopted by many pilots.

FOR USE IN: Urban, post-urban, and high-density terrestrial environments. High O2 concentration preferred.
FOR USE AGAINST: Organic targets; hardened targets vulnerable to caustic/corrosive degradation; most foliage.
NOTES: Dispersion is true directional and involves aerosolized component – avoid danger by supplying end-users with respiratory equipment (specifications noted on canister).

bondPowers.name: Strength Beyond Strength
bondPowers.description: You can call on your inner reserves of willpower to act with incredible athleticism, speed, or strength. For the rest of the scene, you can’t roll less than a 10 on any checks involving physical activity (e.g., running, jumping, climbing, hand-to-hand combat, etc). Treat any roll of 9 or lower as if you rolled a 10.

bondPowers.name: Absolute Meat
bondPowers.description:
If you concentrate and grit your teeth, your personal strength verges on superhuman. You can take 2 Stress and roll a skill check to do one of the following:
  • Bust through a wall, door, or floor, even reinforced, with nothing but your body
  • Lift, push, or drag a vehicle, mech, or other tremendous weight a short distance
  • Withstand forces far beyond the human body such as gale force winds, a mech’ s strength, or the pull of the void.
Your action has increased effect if successful.

bondAnswers: Cybernetic augmentation, laced through your limbs.
minorIdeal: I protected someone weaker than myself.

armor.flavorDescription: The heaviest hardsuits. They are always powered and up-armored with thick, composite armor. Heavy hardsuits often feature integrated weapons, powerful mobility suites, and – by augmenting their user’s strength – allow their user to field much heavier weapons than normal infantry can typically carry. Heavy hardsuits are in decline now that half-size chassis are popular, but they are still common among private militaries and middle-tier Diasporan armed forces.

weapons.flavorDescription: Heavy signature weapons are missile tubes, heavy lasers, light machine gun, or exotic rifles.
Light signature weapons might be oversized revolvers, braces of pistols, and submachine guns.

gear.flavorDescription: A powered third arm mounted on a bracket on the hardsuit. Tertiary arms are powered and controlled using the same neural bridge processes that allow hardsuits to respond to user input. They can be equipped with manipulators to allow for fine motor control, weapons to enhance combat efficacy, or specialty tools.
